instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP5V_S4RS3: What is PP5V_S4RS3? PP5V_S4RS3 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PM_SLP_SUS_L:
What is PM_SLP_SUS_L? 
The "PM_SLP_SUS_L" signal in a MacBook is related to the power management of the device, specifically concerning the 'suspend to RAM' state or S3 state. It's an active-low signal that, when asserted (low voltage), indicates the system should enter or is in the S3 sleep state. .
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER_EN: What is SMC_ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good” and is required for the machine to power on & post..
definitions.PCH_DSWVRMEN:
What is PCH_DSWVRMEN? DSWVRMEN stands for DeepSx Well On-Die Voltage Regulator Enable. This signal enables the internal DSW 1.05 V regulators and must be always pulled-up to PPVRTC_G3H 3.3 volts.
If this signal is not being asserted (i.e., not enabled), the on-die voltage regulators responsible for supplying power in deep sleep states may not be active. This could lead to the MacBook failing to exit from a deep sleep state or having issues when trying to enter one, contributing to a scenario where the device does not power on.

If the signal is not present or not at the correct levels, it could indicate a problem with the Platform Controller Hub (PCH) itself..
definitions.PCH_INTRUDER_L: What is PCH_INTRUDER_L? PCH_INTRUDER_L is a signal that tells the machine the case has been opened by an intruder when it is low, the _L means it is present when it is low. This signal should always be high in a Macbook since it doesn’t use intrusion detection. .
definitions.RTC_RESET_L: What is RTC_RESET_L? RTC_RESET_L is a reset signal that is present when the signal is low, the _L means it is asserted when the voltage is low. The RESET signal will keep the PCH from turning on or booting up the machine. .
definitions.PCH_SRTCRST_L: What is PCH_SRTCRST_L? PCH_SRTCRST_L is a reset signal present for the RTC circuit that asserts when it is low in voltage, that is what _L means..
definitions.PCH_INTVRMEN:
What is PCH_INTVRMEN? PCH_INTVRMEN is an Internal Voltage Regulator Enable: When pulled high, this signal enables
the internal 1.05 V regulators for the Suspend well in the PCH. This signal must
remain asserted for the VRMs to behave properly (no glitches allowed).
This signal must be pulled-up to VCCRTC on desktop platforms and may
optionally be pulled low on mobile platforms if using an external VR for the
VCCSUS rail.
definitions.3V42_G3H: What is 3V42_G3H? This is shorthand for PP3V42_G3H which is one of the first power rails that must turn on in older Macbooks that use a magsafe charger in order for them to get a light on the charger. This power rail powers the onewire circuit and the SMC, which are necessary for the machine to communicate with the charger and get it to turn on, as well as begin the bootup sequence. .
definitions.3V3_SUS: What is 3V3_SUS? 3V3_SUS is an abbreviation for PP3V3_SUS. These are interchangeable. The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
I'm working on <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board, which came to me with description: "Turned off by itself, after a while turned on, but SSD wasn't detected. Now has no reaction for charger". 

My observations:

- board is clean, no corrosion, no water damage, no mechanical damage.
- there is no green light when charger plugged in
- I have discovered, that <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> is missing and has  low reading - 0,007V to ground in diode mode. After further inspection I found out, that short is caused by SMC itself. I have removed SMC and replaced it with one from the same board. <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> is back now, I have green then orange light on charger, but no fan spin. 

Other measurements: 

- <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> - 8,57V
- <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3,42V
- <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> - 3,35V
- <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> - 5,12V
- <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3,31V
- [B]<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> - 0V (0,390V to ground)[/B]
-[B] <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> - 0V (0,390V to ground)
 -<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS_EN</SIGNAL> - 0V (0,495V to ground)
- <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> - 0V [B](not pulsing)[/B]
- <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> - 0V (not pulsing)[/B]

I already have tried another SMC from <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board, but it behaves the same.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
PCH must first release <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL>.
It expects <SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> and good RTC signals.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
These are reading for lines you mentioned:

<SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> is 3,42V
<SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL> is 3,22V
<SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> is 3,42V
<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> is 3,22V

RTC signals: 

<SIGNAL>PCH_CLK32K_RTCX</SIGNAL> is 0,441V
<SIGNAL>PCH_INTRUDER_L</SIGNAL> is 2,35V
<SIGNAL>PCH_INTVRMEN</SIGNAL> is 3,22V
<SIGNAL>PCH_SRTCRST_L</SIGNAL> is 3,3V
<SIGNAL>RTC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is 3,3V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Looks like bad PCH.
It has all required signals, but doesn't want to release <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL>.
Maybe overvoltage on <SIGNAL>3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> power rail affected PCH too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>
threads.message: For me it sounds a bit strange, that it could kill PCH.. Is it worth to try changing bios? Or in this state it's pointless?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Yes, I know that. Just thought, that my multimeter is too slow to catch short pulse on this line and bad bios cause PCH to cut it off.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
BIOS chip (<CHIP>U6100</CHIP>) requires 3V power.
It doesn't play anything until <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> appears...

Heat PCH with quality flux and pray.
